{{distinguish|MusÃ©e d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris}} {{foreignchar|Musee National d'Art Moderne|Ã©}} {{Infobox Museum |name = MusÃ©e National d'Art Moderne |image = |caption = |imagesize = 220 |map_type = |latitude = |longitude = |established = 1947 |dissolved = |location = [[Centre Pompidou]], place Georges Pompidou, 75004 [[Paris]]. |type = [[Art museum]] |visitors = 2 748 884 visitors (2008) |director = Alfred Pacquement |curator = |publictransit = [[Rambuteau (Paris MÃ©tro)|Rambuteau]], [[HÃ´tel de Ville (Paris MÃ©tro)| HÃ´tel de Ville]] |website = [http://www.centrepompidou.fr/Pompidou/Musee.nsf/0/2986F8A0D35157FBC1256DA40045A27D?OpenDocument&sessionM=3.2&L=1 Official website] }} The '''MusÃ©e National d'Art Moderne''' ({{IPA-fr|myze nasjÉnal daÊ mÉdÉÊn}}, ''National Museum of Modern Art'') is the national museum for [[modern art]] of [[France]]. It is located in [[Paris]] and is housed in the [[Centre Pompidou]] in the [[4th arrondissement]] of the city. Created in [[1947]], it was then housed in the [[Palais de Tokyo]] and moved to its current location in [[1977]]. The museum has the second largest collection of modern and [[contemporary art]] in the world, after the [[MOMA]] in New York, with more than 70,000 works of art. These works include painting, architecture, photography, cinema, new media, sculpture and design. A part of collection is on exhibit in a 14,000 square meters space divided between two floors of the Centre Pompidou, one for modern art (from 1905 to 1960) and the other for contemporary art (from 1960). The works displayed often change in order to show to the public the variety and depth of the collection. Many major temporary exhibitions of modern and contemporary art have taken place in a separate floor over the years, among them many one-person exhibitions. Since 2010, the museum displays also unique, temporary exhibitions in its provincial branch, the [[Centre Pompidou-Metz]], in a 10,000 square meters space divided between 3 galleries.
==Collections==
=== Modern Art (1905-1960) === Many styles of modern art, including [[Fauvism]], [[Expressionism]], [[Cubism]], [[Dada]], [[Abstract art]], [[Surrealism]] are represented with works by [[Matisse]], [[AndrÃ© Derain]], [[Maurice de Vlaminck]], [[Raoul Dufy]], [[Albert Marquet]], [[Le Douanier Rousseau]], [[Paul Signac]], [[Georges Braque]], [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Fernand LÃ©ger]], [[Juan Gris]], [[Ernst Ludwig Kirchner]], [[August Macke]], [[Alexej von Jawlensky]], [[Emil Nolde]], [[Oskar Kokoschka]], [[Otto Dix]], [[George Grosz]], [[Kurt Schwitters]], [[Marcel Duchamp]], [[Francis Picabia]], [[Carlo CarrÃ ]], [[Umberto Boccioni]], [[Giacomo Balla]], [[Gino Severini]], [[Marc Chagall]], [[Natalia Gontcharova]], [[Mikhail Larionov]], [[Alexander Rodchenko]], [[FrantiÅ¡ek Kupka|Kupka]], [[Piet Mondrian|Mondrian]], [[Theo Van Doesburg]], [[Paul Klee]], [[Vassili Kandinsky]], [[Kasimir Malevich]], [[Jacques Villon]], [[Robert Delaunay|Robert]] and [[Sonia Delaunay]], [[Georges Rouault]], [[Balthus]], [[Max Beckmann]], [[Brancusi]] and [[Alexander Calder|Calder]], [[ChaÃ¯m Soutine|Soutine]], [[Marc Chagall]], [[Amadeo Modigliani|Modigliani]], [[Kees Van Dongen]], [[Jean Arp]], [[Giorgio de Chirico]], [[AndrÃ© Breton]], [[Salvador Dali]], [[Magritte]], [[Max Ernst]], [[Joan MirÃ³|Miro]], [[Man Ray]], [[Alberto Giacometti]], [[RenÃ© IchÃ©]], [[Nicolas de StaÃ«l]], [[AndrÃ© Masson]], [[Yves Tanguy|Tanguy]], [[Jean Tinguely]], [[Yves Klein]], [[Jackson Pollock|Pollock]], [[Mark Rothko]], [[Barnett Newman]], [[Willem de Kooning]], and [[Francis Bacon (painter)|Francis Bacon]].
=== Contemporary art (from 1960) === [[Pop Art]], [[Nouveau RÃ©alisme]], [[Conceptual art]] and other tendencies or groups are represented with works by [[Andy Warhol]], [[Rauschenberg]], [[Arman]], [[CÃ©sar Baldaccini|CÃ©sar]], [[Niki de Saint-Phalle]], [[Yaacov Agam|Agam]], [[Vasarely]], [[Beuys]], [[Dubuffet]], and [[Louise Bourgeois]].
Works of architecture and design include [[Philippe Starck]], [[Jean Nouvel]], and [[Dominique Perrault|Perrault]].
